definition: making a deer out to be a horse (idiom); deliberate misrepresentation
finger/to point at or to/to indicate or refer to/to depend on/to count on/(of hair) to stand on end
deer
variant of 為|为[wei4], because of/for/to
because of/for/to
variant of 為|为[wei2]/as (i.e. in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do
as (in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do/by (in the passive voice)
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]

sentences.english: You might have heard the saying a camel is a horse designed by committee.
sentences.chinese: 你可能曾经听说过委员会设计过一个指鹿为马的故事。

sentences.english: Lomborg pretends otherwise because he disagrees with the priorities they set.
sentences.chinese: 隆伯格指鹿为马，只不过因为他反对别人订定的顺序。

sentences.english: But why is this era of taking rubbish to be cream still far from its end?
sentences.chinese: 但是为什么指鹿为马的时代仍然没有结束？

sentences.english: Interpreting is not the same as reviewing a work of art;
sentences.chinese: 所谓指鹿为马，今日是处处一现实。

definition: lit. to invert black and white (idiom); to distort the truth deliberately/to misrepresent the facts/to invert right and wrong
to confuse black and white/to say that black is white/fig. not to distinguish right from wrong
to confuse right and wrong (idiom)
to invert right and wrong
three men talking makes a tiger (idiom); repeated rumor becomes a fact
lit. public opinion is powerful enough to melt metal (idiom)/fig. public clamor can obscure the actual truth/mass spreading of rumors can confuse right and wrong
to speak off the cuff/to casually opine
lit. to graft flowers onto a tree/to surreptitiously substitute one thing for another (idiom)
to cover up one's faults (idiom)/to whitewash
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
can't tell black from white (idiom); unable to distinguish wrong from right
lit. a thief crying "Stop the thief!" (idiom)/fig. to accuse sb of a theft and try to sneak away oneself/to cover up one's misdeeds by shifting the blame onto others
lit. a monkey wearing a hat (idiom)/fig. worthless person in imposing attire
to be glib in one's speech and wear an ingratiating expression (idiom)
to pass the misfortune on to sb else (idiom); to blame others/to pass the buck
lit. the fox exploits the tiger's might (idiom); fig. to use powerful connections to intimidate people
